Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematical models that describe the physical reality often exhibit erratic behavior, and include small noise accounting for external perturbations. A fundamental problem is to understand the long term behavior of such systems. The origins of this problem go back to one of the oldest questions in dynamics- "Is the Solar System stable?"-which remains largely unsolved to this day. Instability turns out to be a rather typical regime. A conjecture formulated by V.I. Arnold in 1964 asserts that even simple mechanical systems, modeled as integrable Hamiltonian systems, start to exhibit chaotic and unstable behaviors when they become subjected to small, external perturbations. Despite recent progress in the understanding of this problem, a comprehensive chart of the routes yielding instability and chaos is far from completion. Most current approaches apply only to perturbations of special types, and of very small sizes. This limitation makes it difficult to analyze realistic models. The objective of this project is to develop new methods to analyze the effects of realistic perturbations on integrable Hamiltonian systems. The proposed research considers general types of perturbations, which are not necessarily of an extremely small size, and aims to formulate rigorous results that can be applied to concrete models. Particularly, the conditions considered on these systems are explicit and verifiable, rather than of generic type. The approach intends to expand and innovate techniques from differential, algebraic, low dimensional, and symplectic topology. This machinery will be used in tandem with methods based on normal hyperbolicity, perturbation theory, KAM and Aubry-Mather theories, pseudo-holomorphic curves, and random dynamics.

A significant strength of the proposed approach is its applicability to practical situations. This research yields recipes to increase the energy of physical systems with small forcing, with potential applications to particle accelerators, plasma confinement devices, chemical reactions, astrodynamics, and dynamical astronomy. The results from the proposed investigation on instability in the three-body problem can be applied to design fuel efficient trajectories for spacecrafts to explore the Solar System, or to change the orbits of satellites in specific fashions. As an example, one of the methods discussed in this research has been used to design the trajectory of the current NASA's GRAIL mission to the Moon, which begun on January 1st, 2012. The study of random perturbations of deterministic systems proposed in this project plays a key role in modeling of climate change. In addition, this project will pro-actively engage students, including members of underrepresented groups, in educational and research activities, and will contribute to the professional growth of K-12 educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most physical systems in the real world exhibit some degree of instability: their state can change dramatically over time when they are acted upon even slightly. In some applications, such as in particle accelerators and plasma confinement devices, instability can be a nuisance. In some others, such as in space mission design, instability can be useful, as one can use the influence of Sun, Moon, etc., to design fuel efficient spacecraft trajectories. This project has been devoted to analyze instability in dynamical systems via geometric and topological methods. The newly developed methodology has the benefit that it can be used in both theoretical studies, to advanced the fundamental understanding of instability in a large class of mathematical models, and in practical applications. Analytical arguments can be combined with rigorous computer experiments. Real data can be effectively incorporated into the models. A great deal of this work has been devoted to Hamiltonian systems, which refer to a large class of mechanical system that obey the law of conservation of energy. A special class of such examples can be found in Celestial Mechanics; for example, the motion of spacecrafts or asteroids is virtually free of energy loss. The main outcome of this research has been the  development of a geometric / topological framework that can be used to explicitly extract and describe different mechanisms of instability. By learning how instability occurs in general classes of Hamiltonian systems, one is able, for example, to design efficient spacecraft trajectories, or to control plasma dynamics. Other applications are concerned with the long-term dynamics of planets and asteroids. Instability also appears in systems that are subjected to random forcing. The methodology developed in this research extends to detecting and analyzing instability scenarios in such systems as well. The main outcomes are the following:

1. Explained how instability can occur in random perturbations of conservative mechanical systems (i.e., those for which the total energy is the sum of the kinetic and the potential energy).

2. Proved the existence of unstable trajectories in multi-dimensional mechanical systems consisting of penduli and rotators with weak, periodic coupling.

3. Studied the existence of unstable trajectories that travel throughout the whole phase space (modulo energy constraints).

4. Developed methods to design optimal spacecraft trajectories from Earth to Moon (or planets).

5. Used  topological data analysis to identify certain types of bifurcations in stochastic differential equations with slowly evolving parameters.   

The intellectual merit of this work resides with the development of  a powerful and  versatile methodology to detect and analyze instability in large classes of systems. The broader impacts reside with the broad range of applications including those to space mission design, dynamical astronomy, climate science, genetic regulatory systems, and preventive medicine. A special focus of this project has been on organizing educational and training experiences for undergraduate students, particularly for members of under-represented groups (women, Hispanics, low income and first generation college students).
